title: When will the U.S. leveraged loan default rate reach or exceed 6.0% in the second half of 2020?
preds: No recent updates on the main site but here shows it potentially ticking back down. Looks like negligible chance it exceeds before end of the question. https://individuals.voya.com/insights/investment-outlook/senior-loan-talking-points
October dropped to 3.88. +7 to not before January 2021.
Leveraged loan rate going down now. There's still a non-zero chance that it ramps up but feels like that gets slimmer by the day.
Capitulating, Sept at 4.17 looks a lot like August. Hattip @johnydog for a well stated case giving me the courage to change.

Default rate is slowing but concerns remain. Starting to think that 5 percent is a more likely target than the full 6 percent. [1] [1] https://www.fitchratings.com/research/corporate-finance/fitch-us-leveraged-loan-default-insight-default-rate-to-rise-ninth-straight-month-top-loans-of-concern-total-increases-18-09-2020
Updated to 4.13 for September 30. Looks very unlikely it exceeds 6 by the end of the year. If another coronavirus relief bill gets enacted I think the chances of November or December drop even more.

Fitch Ratings expects the TTM institutional term loan default rate to finish higher for the ninth consecutive month, potentially reaching 4.6% from 4.3% at August end. September volume registers a modest $1 billion thus far, with filings from iQor US Inc. and Town Sports International Inc., though there could be another $3.5 billion coming. Travelport LLC’s sizable distressed debt exchange (DDE) along with J Jill Group’s restructuring and filings from Chief Power LLC and FTS International Inc. are names to watch. The default pace has certainly slowed from the $9.6 billion monthly average occurring over April through July, but activity is expected to remain elevated throughout the year and into 2021. In March, Fitch projected a two-year cumulative base case default of about 15% by YE 2021, with 5%–6% forecast for YE 2020. We expect the default rate to finish the year at the lower end of our base case range. The YTD default rate is 3.7% on $53.2 billion of volume. It would take another $19 billion to reach 5%. https://www.fitchratings.com/research/corporate-finance/fitch-us-leveraged-loan-default-insight-default-rate-to-rise-ninth-straight-month-top-loans-of-concern-total-increases-18-09-2020

It's been a long time since the index has shown any changes, it's close is now
4.08% (as of 31 August 2020)
4.13% (as of 17 September 2020) Although the curve appears to be flattening, my guess is the worst is yet to come, and since a decision about another stimulus package is put on hold on behalf of a Republican Senate majority, the situation for businesses amid increasing infection incidence in the US, it will accelerate through fall. My prediction for months' ends:
4.35%est. as of 30 September 2020
4.88%est. as of 31 October 2020 (at least one major shale oil/gas producer, e.g. OXY or servicing company)
5.55%est. as of 30 November 2020 (at least one major cruise line company, e.g. NCLH)
6.01%est. as of 15 December 2020
6.18%est. as of 31 December 2020 EDIT:
It seem's like the market is bracing for something big:
From the worst 50 performers by daily return as of 22 September 2020, roughly two thirds were from or in any way connected to the financial services industry, among them all big names of Wall St. My possible interpretations are:
a/ Either the stock market has once and for all given up hope for a second term of 45 POTUS and written off any chances for continued term and rule of lax regulations, low tax rates on asset returns and any wish and dream the financial industry could ever have, being read off their lips by S. Mnuchin (SOT) could end soon.
b/ or the market starts pricing in the conversion of the once economic crisis triggered by the pandemic into a financial crisis, in which the financial sector will lose the ability to generate fees on diverse business field while at the same time market volatility (FX, rates, equities) and asset devaluation could cause write-offs and p&l losses exceeding the stress scenarios tested by the FED, and causing yet another case "Lehman Bros.", where liabilities will exceed assets and insolvency may be become inevitable.
c/ the current market condition on core mobility and industrial markets make a big default of a very large company more probable, the longer they last:
Vulnerable companies are:
GE
Boeing
for several strategic reasons and in both cases for reasons of bad investment decisions and prolonged mismanagement.
GE is currently missing the business with aircraft turbines, and has to wind down its business with coal-fired power plants sooner or later causing write-offs of 8bn USD or more.
Boeing will lose some 25bn USD on the 737 MAX-8 grounding by Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and a reputational damage that is hard to put into figures. Procedures within Boeing have obviously deteriorated quality under the protectionist fostering by the FAA, which has now been forced to wake up and put Boeing under more scrutiny. Their other flagship product Dreamliner is now in trouble for having construction and manufacturing  deficiencies that Boeing knew about but ignored, and that the FAA obviously did not want to find checking... Hard to imagine, that either GE or Boeing went bankrupt; on the other hand, they are so deep in the "spiral of death" of bad management, lack of strategy, bad luck in trouble and maybe even problems funding on the bond/leveraged loan markets that they or at least one of them might just collapse if the markets acknowledge the full risk. Either of them would then be large enough to shake all markets and maybe even cause another financial crisis, since each of them has probably a double to triple digit figure of billions USD debt notional outstanding. I'll keep watching both, and the financial sector as well.
-5% to Sept/Oct, -10% to November/December, +15% to 'Not before'. September rate barely moved up from  August.
Decided to be more aggressive on this, likelihood of it exceeding in the next three months seems pretty low to me, I think 1 in 5 is a good value to go with for that.

+14 to not before January 2021. There's been a surprisingly long period of quiet on the source site but I found this which appears to reference more recent numbers (up to September 10). If this is accurate it looks like September default rate didn't increase from August. https://individuals.voya.com/insights/investment-outlook/senior-loan-talking-points

4.08% in August. Corporate profits for second quarter way down.  Only a bit over three months to go so maybe never make it to 6%. The economy is picking-up. My state is 87% if what it was pre-covid says our Governor. 
https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/us-leveraged-loan-default-rate-rises-to-4-08-in-august-60213008

Is the news getting any better? Has Congress passed a bill to help out? What are we doing differently today vs. May? Can the Fed do much more? Have airlines, hotels, restaurants, theaters, public transport, or shopping malls found a solution?

August 31, 4.01 
Moving some into the Sept Oct range. The rolling rate still makes it tricky.

It doesn't look too good for MGM Resorts at the moment (which would be big default...) "MGM Resorts is laying off 18,000 workers who had been on furlough since March terminating a quarter of its pre-pandemic workforce" https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-8674747/MGM-Resorts-laying-18-000-workers-furlough.html

reducing my bold past bet of Yes, and Soon!.... https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=7e46a740-47c4-41c3-b10e-4690970e502e  At the moment, the "Negative Nancy's" or looking to take a hit... But I believe the (in)vested interests are all trying to talk themselves out of trouble...and once things start to go, they'll spiral fast...

Updating per new August data and passage of time. Rate of growth slowing. Spreadsheet and graph [1].  [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=2054366491
More of a return investment in an otherwise no deposit no return market. But given the loss of GDP and slower supply chain management, the default rate is rising.
Roughly 2 pts in 5months puts it in Dec / Jan timeframe. However, there may be a desire to declare in the current calendar year so one can start clean in the new year.

If the average increase of 0.4% from April-August resumes, it will take until January. Maybe August was an outlier in that the stock market sugar rush and rebound in junk bonds helped to "postpone reality" but it would be foolish not to listen to the recent data at all. Revised from 0/7/73/20 to 0/0/65/35
The index is at 4.08% (+0.06% points) as of 19 August 2020

I'm estimating 5.1% in December. I think most companies that had strategic reasons to CHOOSE bankruptcy have already done so. Most companies that want to make it through at this point can convince lenders to stick with them for a bit longer

Many factors involved in this so I'm mostly basing this on gut and what happened in 2009. In my mind the biggest factor is that the government response to the pandemic has been good. The FED lowered rates and made loans available quickly, the CARES act seemed to provide good assistance for businesses. I'd guess the climb in leverage loan default will be slower than we saw in 2008 and 2009 for this reason, and it's possible (if the government continues to play an effective role) that these default rates don't exceed 6%. I'd guess they probably will, but I think there's good reason to believe it won't shoot up as fast as in the last recession. Leveraged loan default rate chart from the great recession is on slide 5 at this link (pdf download): https://www.chicagofed.org/~/media/others/events/2010/private-equity-conference/07-21-coffey-presentation-pdf.pdf
FRED GDP growth just for referencing when the recession hit last time to compare to the leveraged loan rates around that time: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CPGDPAI
-1% to July/August, -11% to September/October, +8% to November/December, +4% to 'Not before'
If you are going to foldem, get it done in the calendar year and move on.

Very broadly working on 90% chance of going above 6% in the next twelve months. From looking at the 2008 data it looked like it shot up quite quickly so if we say uniform distribution over the next 6 months which would seem to argue for something like 30% in each bucket from September. However, it feels to me things are probably less likely to happen in the immediate 2 months though as things have been opening back up, plus a lot of potential reasons to thing companies will try and hang on into the new year (Christmas trading for retailers, presumably new congress/president support package).
4.02 prediction for August. Still looks like it will take some major bankruptcies to drive it over the top.
Right now is 3.9; if it changes will be after November.
Significant update, assuming we'll cross 6% sooner than I expected last time. My best guess now is that it will hit 6.2% in December. I no longer think the Sep-Oct bucket is impossible.

It might go over 6 but predictions so far are lower. 4% now. https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/us-leveraged-loan-default-rate-tops-4-as-oil-gas-pumps-out-sector-record-59766272

The calvary have been blocked by Congress who cannot seem to get out their own way. CEO's are struggling to keep their pay packages intact by stiffing shareholders. Our leadership meanwhile fiddles with interviews that prove incompetence and disregard for everyone else while fancying himself a deal maker. Yet the Fed keeps things afloat by buying with money so fresh the ink is not dry.
-10% to to September/October, +6% to November/December, +4% to 'Not before'. Time Decay.

Share of "Weakest Link" Companies with Corporate Credit Rating of B- or lower and a negative outlook from S&P Global Ratings as of 30 June 2020: 25%
https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/leveraged-loan-news/after-covid-19-onset-25-of-all-us-leveraged-loans-are-now-weakest-links- "With the coronavirus pandemic shuttering businesses and wreaking havoc on the U.S. economy, companies are increasingly drawing on their bank lines to lock in liquidity. Of the 329 Weakest Links [issuers; 25% of total] tracked by LCD, 72 are included on LCD's revolver drawdown tracker — a list and industry breakdown of companies that have drawn their revolvers since early March, when effects of the coronavirus pandemic began to take root in the US economy."
[...]
"Some notable exceptions include Cirque Du Soleil Canada Inc., Men'sMen's Wearhouse, Hertz Global Holdings Inc. and CEC Entertainment Inc. These borrowers were not in the Weakest Links cohort at the end of 2019."
[...]
"The highest number of new additions and the overall number of Weakest Links came from electronics/electric (LCD's proxy for the technology sector), healthcare and business equipment/services. These sectors are also the three biggest industries in the loan market overall, collectively accounting for 34% of the $1.2 trillion institutional loan market, based on the S&P/LSTA Index." Also interesting: this is what prevented issuers from defaulting so far https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/eyeing-relief-us-leveraged-loan-issuers-continue-to-amend-covenants-59460304 The high occurrence of the covenant relief so far also implies that this measure will soon no longer be available, if the pandemic stretches further over time.

Fitch reports that the current default rate stands around 4% with a target 5-6% by year's end. [1] [1] https://www.fitchratings.com/research/corporate-finance/fitch-us-leveraged-loan-default-insight-19-06-2020

Up to 3.7% for July. This is certainly inching more and more likely with many sectors in trouble - oil and gas being the reason that we went from 3.48 to 3.7. This still has the potential to be a rather slow burn though. It would need a major player (AMC, Carnival) to not be able to secure more debt and plunge into Chapter 11. That certainly gets more likely by the day for both of them, as well as other industries.
Lack of trillions in income support or renewed business support could pull more pain into this calendar year.
-1% to July/August, -10% to September/October, -5% November/December, +16% to 'Not before'

Loan manager consensus is 5.3% with a range of 4% to 6% at year-end. In contrast to history, the loan default rate (4.1%) is ahead of HY (3.5%). The current distress ratio in loans has declined to 6.6%, but still ahead of bonds (5.4%0. The culprit seems to be the increased preference for loans over bonds among LBO sponsors, and the concomitant decline in credit quality (only about 25% of the loan market is the highest rated BB today).
https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/lcd-survey-us-leveraged-loan-default-rate-expected-to-rise-to-5-3-by-year-end-59375981

In a nutshell...  https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/leveraged-loan-news/lcd-survey-us-leveraged-loan-default-rate-expected-to-rise-to-53-by-year-end ...yet to see convincing evidence to the contrary.
Moving my eggs to the last basket in sympathy with @fisherdbus and the referenced article.

If I understand the FitchRatings correctly, the leveraged default rate is generally not anticipated to reach 5-6% until 2021. But if there is no economic relief provided to defaulting businesses, it could be as high as 7% by the end of 2020.
Moved some beans into next year. Things could get pretty rocky after Q2 numbers hit the street , however.
Currently at 3.48%, rising but very slowly. Pushing back in response.
The election year will bring another stimulus to hold this off.

It is stated that many projections placed the predicted default rate between 4% and 6%, by years' end.  "Sentiment has no doubt improved from the March 23 distress peak, though these results suggest loan managers are still pricing in, on average, 3% of additional defaults from companies they had previously expected would remain solvent at year-end 2020. The uptick is seen in spite of the stimulus measures and actions taken by loan issuers to shore up liquidity via revolver draws and to secure additional covenant headroom." [1] This 'pricing in of additional 3%' suggests an inflation in prediction percentages, which, (under the proviso that stimulus measures have worked,) will mean the rate will be smaller than estimated, by years' end.  [1] https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/lcd-survey-us-leveraged-loan-default-rate-expected-to-rise-to-5-3-by-year-end-59375981

This to me appears to still be moving slowly. If you look at the revised May to June numbers, we’re on track to hit about 5% this year.  Also, most of the loans that defaulted in April and May of this year were from companies that were in trouble prior to COVID.  Other positives are the fed continuing to put in money, the ratio of downgrades to upgrades improving over May, Global economies reopening, and the number of distressed companies decreasing. Reasons to think this might happen faster include cases rising in the US, potential for a 2nd wave.  My big problem here is this still feels like a slow burn until proven otherwise. Especially if the economy starts to reopen, we should consider regression to the mean. Even though we’re in a recession, it seems like this will be a weird recession. https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/leveraged-loan-news/us-leveraged-loan-defaults-total-23b-in-q2-the-highest-quarterly-volume-since-2009

My two rationals here is the Federal Reserve intervention with the direct purchases of bonds will have some cushioning until the end of the year, second we are looking at a growth of defaults of 80% from here in 6 months, things are not great but they're not that grim. YET!
If we get to 6% that fast, you better tight your belt and secure it.
The Fed time frame has some "hope" baked in the equation. It seems, the Fed has stopped buying, it could be  due to some defaults showing in their holdings and before it becomes and issue they need to asses the next round of liquidity. 
The rational to stop liquidity two weeks already, starts to affect the curve of the balance sheet.

Hattip @SE_Meyer for insights. I'll pull all of the probability into this year since it looks like the ball is rolling and will continue to gather speed. With the overall market so elevated it's difficult to feel the pain on the ground in certain sectors. That may come later.

These may come from a recent number of Ch11-bankruptcy filings by retailers:

Sur La Table (today) It seems the month-end value of the index for June2020 has been revised up meanwhile, to 3.23% (from 3.10% earlier), maybe due to delayed reports about defaults at month's end. It doesn't look too good for Walgreens Boots Alliance either. They posted a quarter to May loss of 1.71bn USD with a big 2bn USD write-off from their UK business in it. EDIT: Dominion recently announed a 10bn USD sale of assets to Berkshire Hathaway https://edition.cnn.com/2020/07/05/energy/berkshire-hathaway-dominion-energy-acquisition/index.html which they explain with a new focus in their business, which on the other hand could also mean they're looking for cash, after they completed two likely overpriced acquisitions in 2016-19, which may have brought along some leverage which includes debt. AFLAC and PNC Financial Service stocks were pretty early to fall (after 20 January 2020), so they were the canaries in this game... Are they still "Monoliners"? Did they make the same mistakes all over again?

Okay this is still best article. https://www.forbes.com/sites/mayrarodriguezvalladares/2020/06/20/corporate-defaults-this-year-are-likely-to-surpass-the-mountain-of-great-recession-defaults/
At about 4% nearing 5% in June probably other articles say.

Before beginning my analysis, I must admit that getting a handle on the timing element of the question has been quite difficult. It's really tempting to substitute the question asked for the much easier "Is the credit market in dire straits right now?" I don't think it takes a veteran bond trader to know that many companies are tetering on the brink of collapse. Default rates are through the roof: 33% in the oil and gas sector and 172% ahead of pace overall based on data from the previous period. [1] But despite these scary numbers, there doesn't seem to be an obvious linear relationship in default rates. In fact, it seems to be the exact opposite in some cases. According to a Thomson Reuters analysis of data published tby the credit rating agency Fitch, the default rate declined in the first three months of the year before skyrocketing in April and May. [2] Most experts seem to be committed to an end of year date for topping that historical benchmark of 6 percent but this doesn't help us much except for perhaps assigning less weight to the probability of not before the new year. [3] If we take the month-on-month April to May change in the rate of +0.29% that puts us at 4.45% Leveraged Default Rate (LDR) by the end of the year. Based on the lack of any linear relationship, I don't put much stock in this number. Especially so with WSJ reporting that bankruptcies were up 48 percent in May, a significant number it has be said but also one that may not move the needle as much as first thought. [4] With all this conflicting evidence in mind, my thinking is that we probably won't see 6 percent before July or August, the rate may even back off slightly. But we will probably see it before the January deadline. I'll be watching this one closely. Comments would be extremely helpful. [1] https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/in-grim-sign-us-leveraged-loan-defaults-set-record-in-april-58437664
[2] https://fingfx.thomsonreuters.com/gfx/mkt/rlgpdwyyzvo/fitch%20loan%20defaults.JPG
[3] https://www.forbes.com/sites/mayrarodriguezvalladares/2020/06/20/corporate-defaults-this-year-are-likely-to-surpass-the-mountain-of-great-recession-defaults/#74f56566166c
[4] https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-business-bankruptcies-rose-48-in-may-11591308842

Hattip @SE_Meyer for references and insights. I'll peanut butter my forecast as timing is everything and nothing is certain. @Bobbiekar52 makes a key observation that this is a 12 month rolling average, more reason to peanut butter the forecast.
Check back with the site monthly to adjust as needed.
https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/campaigns/leveraged-loan

Ok, I'm going to take a shot at this. I don't know anything about this market, so I'll start by warning you to be prepared for a naive view that you should probably ignore.  Currently the US Leveraged Loan Default Rate is 3.1%. Over the last couple of years it's been been mostly in the 0.9 to 2.1% range. During that time it's fluctuated, but has clearly reacted to the COVID outbreak. Since March it's gone up from about 1.8 to 3.1%. Currently it is edging downward slightly. It's a long way to reach 6%. There are several trends going on: 
1) after a massive wave of credit downgrades in April and May, the trend seems to have reversed to a much less horrible rate (but still 3-4x more horrible than pre-COVID)
2) There is a surge in covenant modifications and waivers which could be a sign that the market is seeking to work with lenders and avoid defaults ... or it could simply be a first step towards a wave of defaults.
3) leveraged loans are selling below par in all categories, indicating that the market sees a lot of risk and expects further modifications or defaults
4) the Fed is working hard to back the market and avoid defaults
5) regardless, the new normal isn't working for a lot of companies, and the wave of defaults isn't over, especially in oil & gas, hospitality and retail.
6) if the number of new issuances continues at its current very high pace, that's going to increase the denominator and limit the upward trend of this metric Good news: As pointed out below, the default rate is calculated on a TTM basis, so it's going to take high numbers sustained over months to push it over 6%. The other good news is that because of this calculation method it should be easier to predict than monthly numbers.  Clearly it's going to go up. I've modeled a range of scenarios that seem reasonable (but which are horribly naive and uniformed) and I get something between November and some time in 2021 to hit the 6% mark.  So If I make the assumption that current high default rates continue through the balance of the year. If the number of new issuances continues at its current very high
defaults will begin in Q3 and become significant in Q4 as Fed can/will no longer try to prop up the markets, but rolling average will likely not reflect the carnage until 2021

Index is back up at 3.10% as of 30 June 2020, so there seem to happened defaults of up to 1.9bln USD in the past few days. https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/campaigns/leveraged-loan See graph "Default Rate" Further reading: https://www.fitchratings.com/research/corporate-finance/us-leveraged-finance-clo-weekly-mall-reits-cf-risk-deepens-volker-rule-changes-29-06-2020 "S&P Global Ratings recently forecast that the U.S. trailing-12-month speculative-grade corporate default rate will likely increase to 12.5% by March 2021. But if COVID-19 cases resume their rise later this year or early next year, the default rate could go up to 15.5%.
JPMorgan, meanwhile, predicts a default rate for leveraged loans to just below 10% by the end of this year." https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/japanese-banks-warned-of-covid-19-impact-on-overseas-clo-investments-59253681

Things are continuing to look up. No major rush of June bankruptcies and there is available capital especially via the fed.  https://www.wsj.com/articles/wave-of-corporate-failures-stays-at-bayfor-now-11593509402?st=0yt854g4qza6ymu&reflink=article_copyURL_share

default rates likely to rise over time as typically lag periods of economic/credit weakness as both borrowers and lenders have an incentive to "work together" to avoid defaults typically.  Unprecedented gov't support for borrowers from CARES act (PPP, others) as well as various FRB programs should keep defaults lower than history would suggest in near-term
Slight recalibration after more reading. This should build up over time so moving a little weight to year end. Can modify from there.

Numbers of delinquent mortgages increased in May, however, with the premature opening of the economy there will be a rise that might have been avoided. As a result, consumer confidence will regress as well as spending.  This will cause companies to miss projections, and begin to lose cash.  They will also be less confident of a strong fall.

As of 28 June 2020, Chesapeake Energy Corp. filed for Chapter 11 for defaulting on a revolving credit facility, of which I don't know whether it is some kind of leveraged loan, "the Company will continue to operate its business as 'debtors-in-possession'" in order to enable restructuring financing. A new "Exit Revolving Facility" will be granted. The company had debt of 7.4bn USD on their eoy 2018 balance sheet, but this specific revolving credit will be less than 1bn USD, maybe around 800mn USD of size. It is yet to be seen whether this default will affect other, or all, of the company's credit facilities.
It will be interesting to watch, how and when this first default during the lifetime of the question will feed into the index. EDIT: The June 2020 Index on the S&P Global pages has not moved and is calculated as 2.94% as of now.
So either there has been no kind of debt involved in the Chesapeake default that is classified as "leveraged loan", or a) the 12-m moving sum (and thus the index) is not calculated on a daily basis but at month end, and has not been confirmed as of 30 June 2020, or will be fixed within the next few days.

I probably shouldn’t forecast this since I have no experience in this field. But after reading the information from S&P , a key factor I saw was that the default rate is a 12-month rolling rate, not a single month rate. April was still below average but higher than April of last year. May remained close. At its highest, the default rate 10 years ago was well below 6%. I am assuming time to accumulate based on the rolling average.

Don't know much about this topic, but using question data since March 31, linear growth suggests we wouldn't reach 6% until late January; exponential growth suggests late October. But these things can change fast (I found the chart at the bottom of this article [2] helpful to understand the speed of change during Great Recession), so I'm starting by eyeballing with a good amount of uncertainty. The article https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/hertz-drives-us-leveraged-loan-default-amount-to-6-year-high-58796938 contains most important apects to be considered for this question: - The single default events seem to be aggregated on a daily (or maybe just monthly) basis into total notional defaulted debt (from a certain number of events, which is less relevant here) and then reported in a 12 months-moving sum. On this calculation it depends, whether there a two possible outcomes per basket, or rather roughly 43 business days over the period, where the threshold can be hit. I think it's the latter.
- The 12m-moving sum is then put into relation to the total debt on this specific debt market outstanding, so a percentage index is received.
- The latest large-scale default event of Hertz combined different loans of a total of 10.54 bn USD outstanding, which drive the 12m-moving sum to 37.4 bn USD as of 26 May 2020.
- The total market has been "nearly 1.2 trillion USD" or rather 1,191.1 bn USD, which can be inferred from the latest default ratio of 3.14% - The major share of the market has become "covenant-lite" debt which stands for 80% or ~ 958.9 bn USD and which are unlikely to default in a first wave soon.
On the flipside, 20% of the market or a total notional of 238.2 bn USD has tough covenants which means that certain trigger events will cause a loan to default (technically or by payment outstanding) very mechanically or automatically without much room for maneuver or negotiations. These 20% of debt outstanding are likely to default first, as they are likely floated/issued by companies which have already had a distress/restructuring, an overload of debt or vulnerabilities.
- In the Hertz example, the stock Hertz Global Holdings (HTZ) has been in trouble from 21 February 2020, but from the chart it seems clear that already on 26 March 2020 a default was inevitable, since no government money promised could turn around the share price, and equity holders are eradicated first in case of a bankruptcy. So stock prices may be a good lead indicator of up to two months for an expected default.
- The previous 11 months period also charted in the article from May 2019 to March 2020 (of which only June 2019 and the following feed into the index as of May) seem to be chicken feed compared to what has begun in April 2020 (~7bn USD in defaults) and May 2020, and to what will be coming.
- The total market of leveraged loans will stagnate right now, since risks are obvious, and lenders will not be willing to put their notional at risk at a still relatively low risk premium ("interest rate"), unless interest rates in this segment are significantly rising. With every single debt which is now amortized successfully, the total market and thus the base for our index will be shrinking, so our index has a natural skew towards increasing.
- At the market volume as of 27 May 2020 (the date of the Hertz article), it requires a total notional of 71.5bn USD to surpass the watershed of 6.00% in the index, which leaves a sum of ~ 34.1bn USD for the next few months.
- In a conclusion, it requires a default of three to four issuers of the size of Hertz to meet the prerequisites of the question to be answered "YES". As the stock index S&P 500 contains roughly 500 constituents, only 0.6% to 0.8% of all companies listed there need to default to surpass 71.5bn USD with 95% certainty, which is a value not too far from a normal rate, if you think of companies which have strategic problems like Macy's or Toys'r'us earlier and the Schumpeter model of "Schöpferische Zerstörung" (creative destruction/disruption), which is a driving force in many industries and markets anyway even without the pandemic. When will it happen? I guess it is up to us to follow the news flow on major bankruptcies, and maybe the question should have been listed as a companion question to this one here https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1622-between-15-may-2020-and-30-november-2020-will-any-group-iii-u-s-air-carrier-file-for-bankruptcy EDIT: while bankruptcies can of course happen every business day, the outcome of this question will be determined on a monthly or on a month-to date (?) basis. The fact that the index has fallen from 3.14% (May 2020) to 2.94% (as of 26 June 2020) is obviously due to the fact that a ~4bn amount of defaulted notional in June 2019 will no longer flow into the 12m-moving sum, the residue to reach 6.00% must thus lie at 38 to 39bn USD as of today. EDIT2: I need to step back a little from my assumption of a "shrinking market", as obviously the FED as a lender/buyer of last resort might come into play, as you can read from other S&P articles; at least on the "high yield issuance" side, to which the leveraged loans may add, the FEDs assurance to buy corporate bonds from "fallen angels" of the pandemic in their 9 April 2020 FED bond bulletin seems to have spurred a real bonanza in the new issuance in June 2020. https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/leveraged-loan-news/us-high-yield-bond-market-eyes-record-june-as-fed-fueled-debt-issuance-rolls-on https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/leveraged-loan-news/fed-rally-default-fears-bring-bifurcation-back-to-leveraged-loans
